questions.question_text:
A medical organization recently started accepting payments over the phone. The manager is concerned about the impact of the storage of different types of data.
Which of the following types of data incurs the highest regulatory constraints?

discussion.content:
Initially I chose PHI. Re-read the question and the answer should be PCI.
This is my understanding.
A medical organization (deals with PHI) recently started accepting payments over the phone(accepting payment over the phone by receiving credit card #s from callers). The manager is concerned about the impact of the storage of different types of data (This organization has been dealing with PHI all the time but accepting credit card #s over the phone is new and different type of data to them). 
It is confusing.
PCI is not data. So if payment data, PII is the best answer.

I think the "medical" is to though people off, since the base of the question is talking about payments. and the company is now starting to talk payment over the phone. I think PHI it more important, I feel the authors of the question where talking about PCI
Keywords in question is:"A medical organization" and "the storage of different types of data". That data is PHI, agree with s3curity1
keyword is "PAYMENT" so it should be PCI

Regulation != Legislation. The latter means "by law". The former means "rules by an authority". Sooo, with that in mind, I would say it is PCI. These rules are inherently stricter, albeit the fines for failing to protect PHI are higher.

comments.content: Agree that PCI DSS is stricter than HIPAA. However, PCI DSS is still not a regulation. Or are we a taking the question literally? Wordings of some questions are pain in ***

discussion.content: If you are a merchant accepting credit cards, you are subject to the standards of PCIDSS, which to me means regulated..... and PCI DSS is known to be the most strict because you are subject to vulnerability assessments quarterly as well as after every major change.
Agreed, should be A
I think this is PHI, as this is governed by regulations - HIPAA. PCI is governed by PCI DSS which is a standard, and not a regulation.

questions.question_text: An organization wants to remediate vulnerabilities associated with its web servers. An initial vulnerability scan has been performed, and analysts are reviewing the results. Before starting any remediation, the analysts want to remove false positives to avoid spending time on issues that are not actual vulnerabilities. Which of the following would be an indicator of a likely false positive?

choices.C: The scan result version is different from the automated asset inventory.
choices.A: Reports indicate that findings are informational.
choices.D: "˜HTTPS' entries indicate the web page is encrypted securely.
choices.B: Any items labeled "˜low' are considered informational only.

discussion.content: When conducting a vulnerability scan, it is common for the report to include some findings that are classified as “low” priority or “for informational purposes only”. These are most likely false positives and can be ignored by the analyst when first starting their remediation efforts. "A HTTPS entry that indicates the web page is securely encrypted" is not a false positive, but a true negative (a non-issue). A scan result showing a version that is different from the automated asset inventory is something that should be investigated and is likely a true positive. A finding that shows the scanner compliance plug-ins are not up-to-date would likely also be a true positive that should be investigated.

comments.content: Why? If a new version has been installed it can have new vulnerabilities

discussion.content: This should be C

questions.question_text: An analyst was tasked with providing recommendations of technologies that are PKI X.509 compliant for a variety of secure functions. Which of the following technologies meet the compatibility requirement? (Choose three.)

discussion.content: AES, PKCS, SSL/TLS

according to this, solution should be fine: AES, PKCS, SSL/TLS

"Applications MUST support the encrypted PEM files in the form based on [RFC1423] which is commonly used by historical versions of OpenSSL, with at least the DES-EDE3-CBC, AES-128-CBC and AES-256-CBC modes.

For PKCS#12 [RFC7292] and PKCS#8 [RFC5208] formats, applications MUST support reading objects stored with the following encryption methods:

PBES1 pbeWithMD5AndDES-CBC [RFC2898]
PBES1 pbeWithSHA1And3-KeyTripleDES-CBC [RFC7292]
PBES2 AES-128-CBC (OID: 2.16.840.1.101.3.4.1.2) [RFC2898]
PBES2 AES-256-CBC (OID: 2.16.840.1.101.3.4.1.42) [RFC2898]"
http://david.woodhou.se/draft-woodhouse-cert-best-practice.html

comments.content:
Answer should be 'DEF'. AES has nothing to do with PKI. 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/X.509

discussion.content: DEF is the correct answer. AES is a symmetric cypher and has nothing to do with X.509 which defines the format of public key certificates, so that is not a correct option.
This question was in the exam :)

questions.question_text:
A recent audit included a vulnerability scan that found critical patches released 60 days prior were not applied to servers in the environment. The infrastructure team was able to isolate the issue and determined it was due to a service being disabled on the server running the automated patch management application.
Which of the following would be the MOST efficient way to avoid similar audit findings in the future?

discussion.content:
answer should C or D, when selection MOST efficient one i would go with D, Because implementing service monitroing tool is an additional work load and what if the monitoring tool was not working. 

Therefore, Setting up the service to be startup automatically is the MOST efficient way in this case

comments.content: and in this regard the question seems to know that C is an efficient way but asked for MOST efficient

discussion.content:
In answering most of this question, we always forget that two or three options provided in the answers are all correct but what we should always look out for are "BEST", "MOST", "FIRST" and "NEXT"
they will help in picking the right answers rather than read the questions and just pick answers
In real world D is the right solution. For exam, C seems to be the ask.
The question is asking what is a way to avoid such situations and C would do that. I think the answer is C no?

While solution D should fix the audit finding for the patch management server, how about for other related issues wherein the service is disabled. Letter C, implementing service monitoring to validate and ensure that tools are working properly would be beneficial for the whole company.

choices.B: Create a patch management policy that requires all servers to be patched within 30 days of patch release.
choices.C: Implement service monitoring to validate that tools are functioning properly.
choices.A: Implement a manual patch management application package to regain greater control over the process.
choices.D: Set services on the patch management server to automatically run on start-up.

choices.C: Use Wireshark to export a list

questions.question_text: The Chief Security Officer (CSO) has requested a vulnerability report of systems on the domain, identifying those running outdated OSs. The automated scan reports are not displaying OS version details, so the CSO cannot determine risk exposure levels from vulnerable systems. Which of the following should the cybersecurity analyst do to enumerate OS information as part of the vulnerability scanning process in the MOST efficient manner?

discussion.content:
The Ver command displays what version of MS-DOS or Windows command prompt you're using

ref: https://www.computerhope.com/verhlp.htm

Answer is D

comments.content:
There is no mention of the environment (Windows/Linux) to use the "ver" command.
Option D would be the best choice in this case.

discussion.content: A is correct.. In computing, ver (short for version) is a command in various command-line interpreters (shells) such as COMMAND.COM, cmd.exe and 4DOS/4NT. It prints the name and version of the operating system, the command shell, or in some implementations the version of other commands. It is roughly equivalent to the Unix command uname...wiki
D should be the answer
Should be D
Most efficient would be to use credentialed scanning.

comments.content: I agree. This should be D I believe.
